s.text: GNU is not an operating system but a software suite that runs on many operating systems (mostly Unix-based OS's, but Windows is also supported by many of the packages).
The databases, programming tools and applications included in Linux are worth many thousands more--if you can find them at all for Windows NT.
So, the concerns Linux users have about Windows are related to whether network effects involving proprietary content formats are going to exclude them from some areas of public and commercial life.
GNU is not an operating system but a software suite that runs on many operating systems (mostly Unix-based OS's, but Windows is also supported by many of the packages).
The databases, programming tools and applications included in Linux are worth many thousands more--if you can find them at all for Windows NT.

It doesn't make a big difference to me--or, I suspect, to most Linux users--whether Truitt, Shuman, or any other Windows users like Linux or not (see "").

Shuman also makes the totally unsubstantiated (and untrue) claims that there is very little in the way of application software for Linux and that very few people use it: The latest estimates of the number of Linux users run into the millions--how can that be "so few"?

This is not because Microsoft-based systems are necessarily better, but because Microsoft is the biggest player, and that's what companies are going to focus their efforts on when writing drivers and software; there are, after all, only limited resources for writing drivers and front-end software.
I hope that, as Microsoft matures, so will its attitude toward standards and cooperation.
I hope that, as Microsoft matures, so will its attitude toward standards and cooperation.
Emperors, excepting the period from the late 19 th century to the end of World War II, have yielded little if any power in Japanese society.

I am in favor of choice and freedom though, and your article doesn't exactly encourage readers to exercise their choice and freedom.

Clear support for Sun Java would also be good (and would, in the long run, benefit Microsoft).

The incentive to a commercial author is to get the application on the shelf so she can derive income from it; if Version 1 happens to have bugs in it, the bug fixes become a selling point for Version 2.
